natural solution: We can write the expression as \[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{3} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{4} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{5} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{6} \rfloor} \dotsm \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2015} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2016} \rfloor}.\]For each fraction, the numerator and denominator will be equal (in which case they will cancel), except when the denominator involves a perfect fourth power.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. f n = \<lfloor>n powr (1/4)\<rfloor>"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. g n = \<lfloor>(n+1) powr (1/4)\<rfloor>"
and h2 : "prod f {1..2015} / prod g {2..2016} = 5 / 16"
shows  "prod f {1..2015} / prod g {2..2016} = 5 / 16"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{3} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{5} \rfloor \dotsm \lfloor \sqrt[4]{2015} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{4} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{6} \rfloor \dotsm \lfloor \sqrt[4]{2016} \rfloor}.\] The final Answer is \frac{5}{16}
 ### Proof
 We can write the expression as \[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{3} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{4} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{5} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{6} \rfloor} \dotsm \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2015} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2016} \rfloor}.\]For each fraction, the numerator and denominator will be equal (in which case they will cancel), except when the denominator involves a perfect fourth power.
 Hence, the product reduces to \[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{15} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{16} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{255} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{256} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1295} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1296} \rfloor} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{5}{6} = \boxed{\frac{5}{16}}.\]
 *)

If the ratio of the product of $f(n)$ for $n$ from 1 to 2015 to the product of $g(n)$ for $n$ from 2 to 2016 is $\frac{5}{16}$, verify that this ratio indeed equals $\frac{5}{16}$.

 *)

fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = floor (root 4 x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = floor (root 4 (x+1))"
and h2 : "f 1 = 1"

and h5 : "g 1 = 1"
and h6 : "g 2 = 1"

and h8 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 4 \<and> x \<le> 2015 \<longrightarrow> f x = g (x-3)"
and h9 : "f 2016 = g 2013"
shows  " (\<Prod>x\<in>{1..2015}. f x) / (\<Prod>x\<in>{1..2016}. g x) = 5 / 16"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{3} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{5} \rfloor \dotsm \lfloor \sqrt[4]{2015} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{4} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{6} \rfloor \dotsm \lfloor \sqrt[4]{2016} \rfloor}.\] The final Answer is \frac{5}{16}
 ### Proof

 Hence, the product reduces to \[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{15} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{16} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{255} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{256} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1295} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1296} \rfloor} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{5}{6} = \boxed{\frac{5}{16}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = floor (root 4 x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = floor (root 4 (x+1))"
and h2 : "f 1 = 1"
and h3 : "f 2 = 1"
and h4 : "f 3 = 1"
and h5 : "g 1 = 1"
and h6 : "g 2 = 1"
and h7 : "g 3 = 1"
and h8 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 4 \<and> x \<le> 2015 \<longrightarrow> f x = g (x-3)"
and h9 : "f 2016 = g 2013"
shows  " (\<Prod>x\<in>{1..2015}. f x) / (\<Prod>x\<in>{1..2016}. g x) = 5 / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Two functions $f$ and $g$ are defined where $f(x)$ is the greatest integer less than or equal to the fourth root of $x$ and $g(x)$ is the greatest integer less than or equal to the fourth root of $x+1$. We know that $f(1) = f(2) = f(3) = 1$ and $g(1) = g(2) = g(3) = 1$. For any $x$ from $4$ to $2015$, $f(x) = g(x-3)$. Also, $f(2016) = g(2013)$. What is the ratio of the product of $f(x)$ from $1$ to $2015$ over the product of $g(x)$ from $1$ to $2016$? The final Answer is $\frac{5}{16}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 2015 \<longrightarrow> a = a * floor (n powr (1/4))"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<and> n \<le> 2016 \<and> n mod 2 = 0 \<longrightarrow> b = b * floor (n powr (1/4))"
shows  "a / b = 5 / 16"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{3} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{5} \rfloor \dotsm \lfloor \sqrt[4]{2015} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{4} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{6} \rfloor \dotsm \lfloor \sqrt[4]{2016} \rfloor}.\] The final Answer is \frac{5}{16}
 ### Proof
 We can write the expression as \[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{3} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{4} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{5} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{6} \rfloor} \dotsm \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2015} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2016} \rfloor}.\]For each fraction, the numerator and denominator will be equal (in which case they will cancel), except when the denominator involves a perfect fourth power.
 Hence, the product reduces to \[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{15} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{16} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{255} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{256} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1295} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1296} \rfloor} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{5}{6} = \boxed{\frac{5}{16}}.\]
 *)

fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 2015 \<longrightarrow> a = a * floor (n powr (1/4))"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<and> n \<le> 2016 \<and> n mod 2 = 0 \<longrightarrow> b = b * floor (n powr (1/4))"
shows  "a / b = 5 / 16"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

The final answer is $\frac{5}{16}$.

theorem

theorem

 Compute

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> odd n \<longrightarrow> f n = floor (root 4 n)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> even n \<longrightarrow> g n = floor (root 4 n)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2015 \<longrightarrow> f n \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. 2 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2016 \<longrightarrow> g n \<noteq> 0"
shows  "(\<Prod>n = 1..2015. f n) / (\<Prod>n = 2..2016. g n) = 5 / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Two functions $f$ and $g$ are defined such that $f(n)$ is the floor of the fourth root of $n$ for all odd integers $n \geq 1$ and $g(n)$ is the floor of the fourth root of $n$ for all even integers $n \geq 1$. Moreover, $f(n)$ is nonzero for all $1 \leq n \leq 2015$, and $g(n)$ is nonzero for all $2 \leq n \leq 2016$. What is the value of the product of $f(n)$ from $n=1$ to $n=2015$, divided by the product of $g(n)$ from $n=2$ to $n=2016$? The final answer is $5/16$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = prod (\<lambda>i. \<lfloor>i powr (1/4)\<rfloor>) {1,3..2015}"
and h1 : "y = prod (\<lambda>i. \<lfloor>i powr (1/4)\<rfloor>) {2,4..2016}"
and h2 : "y \<noteq> 0"
shows  "x / y = 5 / 16"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{3} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{5} \rfloor \dotsm \lfloor \sqrt[4]{2015} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{4} \rfloor \cdot \lfloor \sqrt[4]{6} \rfloor \dotsm \lfloor \sqrt[4]{2016} \rfloor}.\] The final Answer is \frac{5}{16}
 ### Proof
 We can write the expression as \[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{3} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{4} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{5} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{6} \rfloor} \dotsm \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2015} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{2016} \rfloor}.\]For each fraction, the numerator and denominator will be equal (in which case they will cancel), except when the denominator involves a perfect fourth power.
 Hence, the product reduces to \[\frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{15} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{16} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{255} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{256} \rfloor} \cdot \frac{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1295} \rfloor}{\lfloor \sqrt[4]{1296} \rfloor} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{5}{6} = \boxed{\frac{5}{16}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = prod (\<lambda>i. \<lfloor>i powr (1/4)\<rfloor>) {1,3..2015}"
and h1 : "y = prod (\<lambda>i. \<lfloor>i powr (1/4)\<rfloor>) {2,4..2016}"
and h2 : "y \<noteq> 0"
shows  "x / y = 5 / 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Let $x$ be the product of the fourth root of all odd integers from 1 to 2015, rounded down to the nearest integer. Let $y$ be the product of the fourth root of all even integers from 2 to 2016, rounded down to the nearest integer. If $y$ is not equal to zero, find the ratio of $x$ to $y$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{16}$.
